1.1: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.
1.2: The earth was barren, with no form of life; it was under a roaring ocean covered with darkness. But the Spirit of God was moving over the water.
1.3: God said, "I command light to shine!" And light started shining.
1.4: God looked at the light and saw that it was good. He separated light from darkness
1.5: and named the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." Evening came, then morning--that was the first day.
1.6: God said, "I command a dome to separate the water above it from the water below it."
1.7: And that's what happened. God made the dome
1.8: and named it "Sky." Evening came, then morning--that was the second day.
1.9: God said, "I command the water under the sky to come together in one place, so there will be dry ground." And that's what happened.
1.10: God named the dry ground "Land," and he named the water "Ocean." God looked at what he had done and saw that it was good.
1.11: God said, "I command the earth to produce all kinds of plants, including fruit trees and grain." And that's what happened.
1.12: The earth produced all kinds of vegetation. God looked at what he had done, and it was good.
1.13: Evening came, then morning--that was the third day.
1.14: God said, "I command lights to appear in the sky and to separate day from night and to show the time for seasons, special days, and years.
1.15: I command them to shine on the earth." And that's what happened.
1.16: God made two powerful lights, the brighter one to rule the day and the other to rule the night. He also made the stars.
1.17: Then God put these lights in the sky to shine on the earth,
1.18: to rule day and night, and to separate light from darkness. God looked at what he had done, and it was good.
1.19: Evening came, then morning--that was the fourth day.
1.20: God said, "I command the ocean to be full of living creatures, and I command birds to fly above the earth."
1.21: So God made the giant sea monsters and all the living creatures that swim in the ocean. He also made every kind of bird. God looked at what he had done, and it was good.
1.22: Then he gave the living creatures his blessing--he told the ocean creatures to increase and live everywhere in the ocean and the birds to increase everywhere on earth.
1.23: Evening came, then morning--that was the fifth day.
1.24: God said, "I command the earth to give life to all kinds of tame animals, wild animals, and reptiles." And that's what happened.
1.25: God made every one of them. Then he looked at what he had done, and it was good.
1.26: God said, "Now we will make humans, and they will be like us. We will let them rule the fish, the birds, and all other living creatures."
1.27: So God created humans to be like himself; he made men and women.
1.28: God gave them his blessing and said: Have a lot of children! Fill the earth with people and bring it under your control. Rule over the fish in the ocean, the birds in the sky, and every animal on the earth.
1.29: I have provided all kinds of fruit and grain for you to eat.
1.30: And I have given the green plants as food for everything else that breathes, including animals, both wild and tame, and birds. And so it was.
1.31: God looked at what he had done. All of it was very good! Evening came, then morning--that was the sixth day.

2.1: So the heavens and the earth and everything else were created.
2.2: By the seventh day God had finished his work, and so he rested.
2.3: God blessed the seventh day and made it special, because on that day he rested from his work.
2.4: That's how God created the heavens and the earth. When the LORD God made the heavens and the earth,
2.5: no grass or plants were growing anywhere. God had not yet sent any rain, and there was no one to work the land.
2.6: But streams came up from the ground and watered the earth.
2.7: The LORD God took some soil from the ground and made a man. God breathed life into the man, and the man started breathing.
2.8: The LORD made a garden in a place called Eden, which was in the east, and he put the man there.
2.9: The LORD God filled the garden with all kinds of beautiful trees and fruit trees. Two other trees were in the middle of the garden. One of these gave life--the other gave the wisdom to know the difference between right and wrong.
2.10: From Eden a river flowed out to water the garden, then it divided into four rivers.
2.11: The first one is the Pishon River that flows through the land of Havilah,
2.12: where pure gold, rare perfumes, and precious stones are found.
2.13: The second is the Gihon River that winds through Ethiopia.
2.14: The Tigris River that flows east of Assyria is the third, and the fourth is the Euphrates River.
2.15: The LORD God put the man in the Garden of Eden to take care of it and to look after it.
2.16: But the LORD told him, "You may eat fruit from any tree in the garden,
2.17: except the one that has the power to let you know the difference between right and wrong. If you eat any fruit from that tree, you will die before the day is over!"
2.18: The LORD God said, "It isn't good for the man to live alone. I will make a suitable partner for him."
2.21: So the LORD God made him fall into a deep sleep, and he took out one of the man's ribs. Then after closing the man's side,
2.22: the LORD made a woman out of the rib. The LORD God brought her to the man,
2.23: and the man exclaimed, "Here is someone like me! She is part of my body, my own flesh and bones. She came from me, a man. So I will name her Woman!"
2.24: That's why a man will leave his own father and mother. He marries a woman, and the two of them become like one person.
2.25: Although the man and his wife were both naked, they were not ashamed.

3.1: The snake was sneakier than any of the other wild animals that the LORD God had made. One day it came to the woman and asked, "Did God tell you not to eat fruit from any tree in the garden?"
3.2: The woman answered, "God said we could eat fruit from any tree in the garden,
3.3: except the one in the middle. He told us not to eat fruit from that tree or even to touch it. If we do, we will die."
3.5: "God understands what will happen on the day you eat fruit from that tree. You will see what you have done, and you will know the difference between right and wrong, just as God does."
3.6: The woman stared at the fruit. It looked beautiful and tasty. She wanted the wisdom that it would give her, and she ate some of the fruit. Her husband was there with her, so she gave some to him, and he ate it too.
3.7: At once they saw what they had done, and they realized they were naked. Then they sewed fig leaves together to cover themselves.
3.8: Late in the afternoon, when the breeze began to blow, the man and woman heard the LORD God walking in the garden. So they hid behind some trees.
3.9: The LORD God called out to the man and asked, "Where are you?"
3.10: The man answered, "I was naked, and when I heard you walking through the garden, I was frightened and hid!"
3.11: "How did you know you were naked?" God asked. "Did you eat any fruit from that tree in the middle of the garden?"
3.12: "It was the woman you put here with me," the man said. "She gave me some of the fruit, and I ate it."
3.13: The LORD God then asked the woman, "What have you done?" "The snake tricked me," she answered, "and I ate some of that fruit."
3.14: So the LORD God said to the snake: "Because of what you have done, you will be the only animal to suffer this curse--For as long as you live, you will crawl on your stomach and eat dirt.
3.15: You and this woman will hate each other; your descendants and hers will always be enemies. One of hers will strike you on the head, and you will strike him on the heel."
3.16: Then the LORD God said to the woman, "You will suffer terribly when you give birth. But you will still desire your husband, and he will rule over you."
3.17: The LORD said to the man, "You listened to your wife and ate the fruit I told you not to eat. And so, the ground will be under a curse because of what you did. As long as you live, you will have to struggle to grow enough food.
3.18: Your food will be plants, but the ground will produce thorns and thistles.
3.19: You will sweat all your life to earn a living; you were made out of soil, and you will once again turn into soil."
3.20: The man Adam named his wife Eve because she would become the mother of all who live.
3.21: Then the LORD God made clothes out of animal skins for the man and his wife.
3.22: The LORD said, "They now know the difference between right and wrong, just as we do. But they must not be allowed to eat fruit from the tree that lets them live forever."
3.23: So the LORD God sent them out of the Garden of Eden, where they would have to work the ground from which the man had been made.
3.24: Then God put winged creatures at the entrance to the garden and a flaming, flashing sword to guard the way to the life-giving tree.

4.1: Adam and Eve had a son. Then Eve said, "I'll name him Cain because I got him with the help of the LORD."
4.2: Later she had another son and named him Abel. Abel became a sheep farmer, but Cain farmed the land.
4.3: One day, Cain gave part of his harvest to the LORD,
4.4: and Abel also gave an offering to the LORD. He killed the first-born lamb from one of his sheep and gave the LORD the best parts of it. The LORD was pleased with Abel and his offering,
4.5: but not with Cain and his offering. This made Cain so angry that he could not hide his feelings.
4.6: The LORD said to Cain: What's wrong with you? Why do you look so angry?
4.7: If you had done the right thing, you would be smiling. But you did the wrong thing, and now sin is waiting to attack you like a lion. Sin wants to destroy you, but don't let it!
4.8: Cain said to his brother Abel, "Let's go for a walk." And when they were out in a field, Cain attacked and killed him.
4.9: Afterwards the LORD asked Cain, "Where is Abel?" "How should I know?" he answered. "Am I supposed to look after my brother?"
4.10: Then the LORD said: Why have you done this terrible thing? You killed your own brother, and his blood flowed onto the ground. Now his blood is calling out for me to punish you.
4.11: And so, I'll put you under a curse. Because you killed Abel and made his blood run out on the ground, you will never be able to farm it again.
4.12: When you try to farm the land, it won't produce anything for you. From now on, you'll be without a home, and you'll spend the rest of your life wandering from place to place.
4.13: "This punishment is too hard!" Cain said.
4.14: "You're making me leave my home and live far from you. I will have to wander about without a home, and just anyone could kill me."
4.15: "No!" the LORD answered. "Anyone who kills you will be punished seven times worse than I am punishing you." So the LORD put a mark on Cain to warn everyone not to kill him.
4.16: But Cain had to go far from the LORD and live in the Land of Wandering, which is east of Eden.
4.17: Later, Cain and his wife had a son named Enoch. At the time Cain was building a town, and so he named it Enoch after his son.
4.18: Then Enoch had a son named Irad, who had a son named Mehujael, who had a son named Methushael, who had a son named Lamech.
4.22: Lamech and Zillah had a son named Tubal Cain who made tools out of bronze and iron. They also had a daughter, whose name was Naamah.
4.23: One day, Lamech said to his two wives, "A young man wounded me, and I killed him.
4.24: Anyone who tries to get even with me will be punished ten times more than anyone who tries to get even with Cain."
4.25: Adam and his wife had another son. They named him Seth, because they said, "God has given us a son to take the place of Abel, who was killed by his brother Cain."
4.26: Later, Seth had a son and named him Enosh. About this time people started worshiping the LORD.

6.3: Then the LORD said, "I won't let my life-giving breath remain in anyone forever. No one will live for more than 120 years."
6.4: The children of the supernatural beings who had married these women became famous heroes and warriors. They were called Nephilim and lived on the earth at that time and even later.
6.5: The LORD saw how bad the people on earth were and that everything they thought and planned was evil.
6.6: He was sorry that he had made them,
6.7: and he said, "I'm going to destroy every person on earth! I'll even wipe out animals, birds, and reptiles. I'm sorry I ever made them."
6.8: But the LORD was pleased with Noah,
6.9: and this is the story about him. Noah was the only person who lived right and obeyed God.
6.10: He had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
6.13: So he told Noah: Cruelty and violence have spread everywhere. Now I'm going to destroy the whole earth and all its people.
6.14: Get some good lumber and build a boat. Put rooms in it and cover it with tar inside and out.
6.15: Make it 133 meters long, 22 meters wide, and 13 meters high.
6.16: Build a roof on the boat and leave a space of about 44 centimeters between the roof and the sides. Make the boat three stories high and put a door on one side.
6.17: I'm going to send a flood that will destroy everything that breathes! Nothing will be left alive.
6.18: But I solemnly promise that you, your wife, your sons, and your daughters-in-law will be kept safe in the boat.
6.21: Store up enough food both for yourself and for them.
6.22: Noah did everything God told him to do.

7.1: The LORD told Noah: Take your whole family with you into the boat, because you are the only one on this earth who pleases me.
7.2: Take seven pairs of every kind of animal that can be used for sacrifice and one pair of all others.
7.3: Also take seven pairs of every kind of bird with you. Do this so there will always be animals and birds on the earth.
7.4: Seven days from now I will send rain that will last for 40 days and nights, and I will destroy all other living creatures I have made.
7.10: Seven days later a flood began to cover the earth.
7.13: On that day Noah and his wife went into the boat with their three sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and their wives.
7.14: They took along every kind of animal, tame and wild, including the birds.
7.15: Noah took a male and a female of every living creature with him,
7.16: just as God had told him to do. And when they were all in the boat, the LORD closed the door.
7.21: Not a bird, animal, reptile, or human was left alive anywhere on earth.
7.24: A hundred fifty days later, the water started going down.

8.1: God did not forget about Noah and the animals with him in the boat. So God made a wind blow, and the water started going down.
8.2: God stopped up the places where the water had been gushing out from under the earth. He also closed up the sky, and the rain stopped.
8.3: For 150 days the water slowly went down.
8.4: Then on the seventeenth day of the seventh month of the year, the boat came to rest somewhere in the Ararat mountains.
8.5: The water kept going down, and the mountain tops could be seen on the first day of the tenth month.
8.8: Noah wanted to find out if the water had gone down, so he sent out a dove.
8.9: Deep water was still everywhere, and when the dove could not find a place to land, it flew back to the boat. Then Noah held out his hand and helped it back in.
8.10: Seven days later Noah sent the dove out again.
8.11: It returned in the evening, holding in its beak a green leaf from an olive tree. Noah knew the water was finally going down.
8.12: He waited seven more days before sending the dove out again, and this time it did not return.
8.13: Noah was now 601 years old. And by the first day of that year, almost all the water had gone away. Noah made an opening in the roof of the boat and saw that the ground was getting dry.
8.14: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month, the earth was completely dry.
8.16: "You, your wife, your sons, and your daughters-in-law may now leave the boat.
8.17: Let out the birds, animals, and reptiles, so they can mate and live all over the earth."
8.18: After Noah and his family had left the boat,
8.19: the living creatures left in groups of their own kind.
8.20: Noah built an altar where he could offer sacrifices to the LORD. Then he offered on the altar one of each kind of animal and bird that could be used for a sacrifice.
8.21: The smell of the burning offering pleased the LORD, and he said: Never again will I punish the earth for the sinful things its people do. All of them have evil thoughts from the time they are young, but I will never destroy everything that breathes, as I did this time.
8.22: As long as the earth remains, there will be planting and harvest, cold and heat; winter and summer, day and night.

9.1: God said to Noah and his sons: I am giving you my blessing. Have a lot of children and grandchildren, so people will live everywhere on this earth.
9.2: All animals, birds, reptiles, and fish will be afraid of you. I have placed them under your control,
9.3: and I have given them to you for food. From now on, you may eat them, as well as the green plants that you have always eaten.
9.4: But life is in the blood, and you must not eat any meat that still has blood in it.
9.7: I want you and your descendants to have many children, so people will live everywhere on earth.
9.8: Again, God said to Noah and his sons:
9.9: I am going to make a solemn promise to you and to everyone who will live after you.
9.10: This includes the birds and the animals that came out of the boat.
9.11: I promise every living creature that the earth and those living on it will never again be destroyed by a flood.
9.14: When I send clouds over the earth, and a rainbow appears in the sky,
9.15: I will remember my promise to you and to all other living creatures. Never again will I let floodwaters destroy all life.
9.16: When I see the rainbow in the sky, I will always remember the promise that I have made to every living creature.
9.17: The rainbow will be the sign of that solemn promise.
9.18: Noah and his sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, left the boat. Ham later had a son named Canaan.
9.19: All people on earth are descendants of Noah's three sons.
9.20: Noah farmed the land and was the first to plant a vineyard.
9.21: One day he got drunk and was lying naked in his tent.
9.22: Ham entered the tent and saw him naked, then went back outside and told his brothers.
9.23: Shem and Japheth put a robe over their shoulders and walked backwards into the tent. Without looking at their father, they placed it over his body.
9.24: When Noah sobered up and learned what his youngest son had done,
9.25: he said, "I now put a curse on Canaan! He will be the lowest slave of his brothers.
9.26: I ask the LORD my God to bless Shem and make Canaan his slave.
9.27: I pray God will give Japheth more and more land and let him take over the territory of Shem. May Canaan be his slave."
9.28: Noah lived 350 years after the flood
9.29: and died at the age of 950.
